title: Campaigners to lobby PM over Malka Leifer extradition bid
text:
Israel's Supreme Court this month overturned a decision to release Ms Leifer on bail.

"We will be asking the Prime Minister to stand up and support the extradition of Malka Leifer publicly and to push the Israeli government to expedite the process and see Malka Leifer back in Australia as quickly as possible," Ms Erlich said.

"We will also be sharing with the Prime Minister the impact this has had and hoping he will take a public interest in seeing this case reach closure.

"We met with Malcolm Turnbull when he was in office. He was very supportive and took this case directly to the Israeli prime minister and raised it directly."

Accused child sex abuser Malka Leifer in February last year. AP

Ms Leifer was previously released on bail and has been absent from some court hearings, saying she suffered from panic attacks and was too unwell to leave her home.

She was subsequently jailed after private investigators filmed her living normally in an orthodox Jewish settlement. Police recommended Israel's deputy health minister face charges over his involvement in the case.

Ms Erlich said nothing short of extradition to Australia would be good enough.

Advertisement

"Absolutely not. Simple as that," she said.

"We're not asking anyone to interfere in the process, we're just asking that it actually take place."

'Enough is enough'

Last week, Liberal MP Dave Sharma told Parliament the case had dragged on for too long.

Mr Sharma is a former Australian ambassador to Israel.

"It is damaging to Israel's reputation, and it is increasingly becoming a point of contention and friction in our otherwise positive and productive relationship with Israel," he said.

"I do not doubt the independence and the integrity of the Israeli legal system, nor do I doubt the commitment of the Israeli Ministry of Justice to pursuing this case. But enough is enough. This case has gone on for far too long.

Advertisement

"We will keep faith with the victims of this awful abuse, and we will be relentless in ensuring that justice is done in this case," he said.

Former Victorian premier Ted Baillieu has lobbied for Ms Erlich and her sister Nicole Meyer, who was also allegedly abused by Ms Leifer.

On Tuesday, Social Services Minister Anne Ruston used the first anniversary of the apology to victims of institutional child sexual abuse in Australia to announce $11.7 million in extra funding for the national redress scheme for survivors.

The funding will help reduce the number of people a survivor may be required to deal with during their application for compensation and see more decision makers hired for the back-logged scheme.
description: The Prime Minister will be asked to help secure the extradition of a former school principal facing 74 charges of rape and child sex abuse.
